a.g: The Prophet frowned and turned away
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
واستأذن ابن أم مكتوم على النبي صلى الله عليه وسلم وعنده رجل من أشراف قريش، فشق ذلك على النبي صلى الله عليه وسلم، فأنزل الله تعالى: " عبس وتولى أن جاءه العمى، وما يدريك لعله يزكى، أو يذكر فتنفعه الذكرى " يعني ابن مكتوم " أما من استغنى فأنت له تصدى" يعني هذا الشريف.
Indeed, Ibn Umm Maktum sought permission to enter upon the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, while there was with him a man from the nobles [ashraf] of Quraysh, and that was burdensome for the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. So Allah, the Exalted, revealed: "He frowned and turned away because the blind man came to him. And what would make you perceive, [O Muhammad], that perhaps he might be purified [yazakka] or be reminded and the remembrance [dhikra] would benefit him? As for he who thinks himself without need, to him you give attention." Meaning Ibn Maktum. "But as for he who came to you striving [while] fearing [Allah], from him you are distracted." Meaning this nobleman.

a.g: Because there came to him the blind man, [interrupting].
But what would make you perceive, [O Muhammad], that perhaps he might be purified

a.g: Or be reminded and the remembrance would benefit him?
As for he who thinks himself without need,
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
ولا تستبعدون رضاه عن العبد بما يغضب به على غيره مهما اختلف مقامهما، ففي القرآن تنبيهات على هذه المعاني لو فطنت وفهمت، فجميع قصص القرآن تنبيهات لأولي البصائر والأبصار حتى ينظروا إليها بعين الاعتبار، فإنما هي عند ذوي الاعتبار من الأسماء. وقد عاتب الله نبيه ﭬ في الإعراض عن عبد والإقبال على عبد، وهما في العبودية سيان ولكن في الحال مختلفان، فقال: " وأما من جاءك يسعى وهو يخشى فأنت عنده تلهى "، وقال في الآخر: " أما من استغنى فأنت له تصدى ".
And do not deem it unlikely that He is pleased with a servant [ʿabd] by that which angers Him concerning another, however much their stations [maqām] may differ. For in the Quran are intimations [tanbīhāt] of these meanings, if you were to be discerning and understand. Indeed, all the narratives of the Quran are intimations for those of insight [baṣāʾir] and vision [abṣār], that they may look upon them with the eye of contemplation [iʿtibār]. For they are, in the sight of those possessed of contemplation, among the signs [āyāt]. And God reproached His Prophet ﷺ for turning away from one servant and turning towards another, while they are equal in servitude [ʿubūdiyya] but differ in state [ḥāl]. So He said: "But as for he who came to you striving, while he fears [God], you are to him inattentive." And He said of the other: "As for he who considers himself self-sufficient, to him you give attention."

a.g: To him you give attention.
And not upon you [is any blame] if he will not be purified.
But as for he who came to you striving [for knowledge]
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
وقد عاتب الله نبيه ﭬ في الإعراض عن عبد والإقبال على عبد، وهما في العبودية سيان ولكن في الحال مختلفان، فقال: " وأما من جاءك يسعى وهو يخشى فأنت عنده تلهى "، وقال في الآخر: " أما من استغنى فأنت له تصدى ".
Indeed, God reproached His Prophet ﷺ for turning away from one servant and turning towards another, and they are equal in servitude [‘ubudiyya] but different in state [hal]. So He said: "And as for he who came to you striving [yas‘a] while he fears [yakhsha], you are from him distracted [talha]." And He said concerning the other: "As for he who considers himself self-sufficient [istaghna], you attend to him [tassadda]."

a.g: While he fears [Allah],
From him you are distracted.
No! Indeed, these verses are a reminder;
So whoever wills may remember it.
[It is recorded] in honored sheets,
Exalted and purified,
[Carried] by the hands of messenger-angels,
Noble and dutiful.
Cursed is man; how disbelieving is he.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
وذكر أنك مخلوق من نطفة قذرة فقال قتل الإنسان ما أكفره من أي شئ خلقه من نطفة خلقه فقدره ثم السبيل يسره ثم أماته فأقبره ثم إذا شاء أنشره
Indeed, He has reminded you that you were created from a base fluid [nutfatin qadhirah]. He said: "Cursed is man [al-insan]! How ungrateful he is! From what thing did He create him? From a sperm-drop [nutfah] He created him and proportioned him. Then He made the way easy for him. Then He caused him to die and buried him. Then, when He wills, He will resurrect him."

a.g: From what substance did He create him?
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
أما تتفكرين أنه مماذا خلقك من نطفة خلقك فقدرك ثم السبيل يسرك ثم أماتك فأقبرك أفتكذبينه في قوله ثم إذا شاء أنشرك فإن لم تكونى مكذبة فما لك لا تأخذين حذرك
Indeed, do you not reflect upon what He created you from? From a drop [nutfah] He created you, then He proportioned you [qaddaraka], then He made the path easy for you [yassaraka], then He caused you to die [amātaka], then He buried you [aqbaraka]. So do you deny Him [tukadhdhibīnahu] in His saying, "Then when He wills, He will resurrect you [ansharaka]"? If you are not a denier, then what is it that prevents you from taking your caution [ḥadhr]?

a.g: From a sperm-drop He created him and destined for him;
Then He eased the way for him;
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
اعلم أن الكبر من المهلكات ولا يخلو أحد من الخلق عن شيء منه، وإزالته فرض عين ولا يزول بمجرد التمني بل بالمعالجة واستعمال الأدوية القامعة له. وفي معالجته مقامان أحدهما استئصال أصله من سنخه وقلع شجرته من مغرسها في القلب. المقام الأول في استئصال أصله، وعلاجه علمي وعملي، ولا يتم الشفاء إلا بمجموعهما: أما العلمي: فهو أن يعرف نفسه ويعرف ربه تعالى ويكفيه ذلك في إزالة الكبر، فإنه مهما عرف نفسه حق المعرفة علم أنه أذل من كل ذليل وأقل من كل قليل، وأنه لا يليق به إلا التواضع والذلة والمهانة، وإذا عرف ربه علم أنه لا تليق العظمة والكبرياء إلا بالله، وأما معرفته نفسه فهو أيضاً يطول ولكن نذكر من ذلك ما ينفع في إثارة التواضع والمذلة، ويكفيه أن يعرف معنى آية واحدة في كتاب الله فإن القرآن علم الأولين والآخرين لمن فتحت بصيرته وقد قال تعالى "قتل الإنسان ما أكفره من أي شيء خلقه من نطفة خلقه فقدره ثم السبيل يسره ثم أماته فأقبره ثم إذا شاء أنشره" فقد أشارت الآية إلى أول خلق الإنسان فهو أنه لم يكن شيئاً مذكوراً وقد كان في حيز العدم دهوراً بل لم يكن لعدمه أول وأي شيء أخس وأقل من المحو والعدم؟ وقد كان كذلك في القدم، ثم خلقه الله من أرذل الأشياء، ثم من أقذرها إذ قد خلقه من تراب، ثم من نطفة، ثم من علقة، ثم من مضغة، ثم جعله عظماً، ثم كسا العظم لحماً، فقد كان هذا بداية وجوده حيث كانت شيئاً مذكوراً، فما صار شيئاً مذكوراً إلا وهو على أخس الأوصاف والنعوت! إذ لم يخلق في ابتدائه كاملاً بل خلقه جماداً ميتاً لا يسمع ولا يبصر ولا يحس ولا يتحرك ولا ينطق ولا يبطش ولا يدرك ولا يعلم، فبدأ بموته قبل حياته وبضعفه قبل قوته وبجهله قبل علمه وبعماه قبل بصره وبصممه قبل سمعه وببكمه قبل نطقه وبضلالته قبل هداه وبفقره قبل غناه وبعجزه قبل قدرته. فهذا معنى قوله "من أي شيء خلقنا الإنسان من نطفة أمشاج" ومعنى قوله "هل أتى على الإنسان حين من الدهر لم يكن شيئاً مذكوراً إنا خلقنا الإنسان من نطفة أمشاج نبتليه" كذلك خلقه أولاً ثم أمنن عليه فقال "ثم السبيل يسره" وهذا إشارة إلى ما تيسر له في مدة حياته إلى الموت. وكذلك قال "من نطفة أمشاج نبتليه فجعلناه سميعاً بصيراً إنا هديناه السبيل إما شاكراً وإما كفورا" ومعناه أنه أحياه بعد أن كان جماداً ميتاً تراباً أولاً ونطفة ثانياً، وأسمعه بعد ما كان أصم، وبصره بعدما كان فاقداً للبصر وقواه بعد الضعف، وعلمه بعد الجهل، وخلق له الأعضاء بما فيها من العجائب والآيات بعد الفقد لها، وأغناه بعد الفقر، وأشبعه بعد الجوع، وكساه بعد العري، وهداه بعد الضلال. فانظر كيف دبره وصوره وإلى السبيل كيف يسره وإلى طغيان الإنسان ما أكفره وإلى جهل الإنسان كيف أظهره؟ فقال "أو لم ير الإنسان أنا خلقناه من نطفة فإذا هو خصيم مبين ومن آياته أن خلقكم من تراب ثم إذا أنتم تنتشرون" فانظر
Know that pride [kibr] is among the destroyers, and no one among creation is free from some measure of it. Its removal is an individual obligation [fard 'ayn], and it is not removed by mere wishing, but rather by treatment and employing the remedies that suppress it. In its treatment are two stations: the first is the eradication of its root from its origin and the uprooting of its tree from its planting place in the heart [qalb]. The first station is in eradicating its root, and its treatment is both intellectual ['ilmi] and practical ['amali], and healing is not complete except by their combination. As for the intellectual: it is that he knows himself and knows his Lord, the Exalted, and that suffices him in removing pride [kibr]. For whenever he knows himself with true knowledge [ma'rifa], he knows that he is more abased than every abased one and less than every insignificant one, and that nothing befits him except humility [tawadu'] and abasement and lowliness. And when he knows his Lord, he knows that grandeur ['azama] and majesty [kibriya'] are not fitting except for Allah. As for his knowing himself, it is also lengthy, but we mention from it what is beneficial in arousing humility [tawadu'] and abasement. It suffices him to know the meaning of a single verse in the Book of Allah, for the Qur'an is the knowledge ['ilm] of the first and the last for one whose insight [basira] has been opened. And He, the Exalted, has said: "Destroyed is man [insan]; how ungrateful he is! From what thing did He create him? From a sperm-drop [nutfa] He created him and proportioned him. Then He made the way [sabil] easy for him. Then He causes him to die and puts him in a grave. Then when He wills, He will resurrect him." Indeed, the verse points to the first creation of man [insan]: he was not a thing mentioned, and he was in the realm of non-existence for ages—indeed, his non-existence had no beginning. And what thing is more vile and less than obliteration and non-existence? He was like that in pre-eternity. Then Allah created him from the vilest of things, then from the filthiest of them, for He created him from dust [turab], then from a sperm-drop [nutfa], then from a clinging clot ['alaqa], then from a lump of flesh [mudgha], then He made him bones, then He clothed the bones with flesh. This was the beginning of his existence when he became a thing mentioned. He did not become a thing mentioned except while being upon the vilest of descriptions and attributes! For he was not created complete at his beginning; rather, He created him an inanimate, dead thing—he did not hear, nor see, nor feel, nor move, nor speak, nor grasp, nor perceive, nor know. He began with his death before his life, and with his weakness before his strength, and with his ignorance before his knowledge ['ilm], and with his blindness before his sight, and with his deafness before his hearing, and with his muteness before his speech, and with his misguidance before his guidance, and with his poverty before his wealth, and with his incapacity before his power. This is the meaning of His saying: "From what thing did He create him? From a sperm-drop [nutfa], a mixture [amshaj]." And the meaning of His saying: "Has there come upon man [insan] a period of time when he was not a thing mentioned? Indeed, We created man [insan] from a sperm-drop [nutfa], a mixture [amshaj], to test him." Likewise, He created him first, then bestowed favor upon him, saying: "Then He made the way [sabil] easy for him." And this points to what was made easy for him during the period of his life until death. And likewise He said: "From a sperm-drop [nutfa], a mixture [amshaj], to test him; so We made him hearing and seeing. Indeed, We guided him to the way [sabil], whether he be grateful or ungrateful." Its meaning is that He gave him life after he was an inanimate, dead thing—dust [turab] first, then a sperm-drop [nutfa]. And He gave him hearing after he was deaf, and gave him sight after he was lacking vision, and strengthened him after weakness, and gave him knowledge ['ilm] after ignorance, and created for him the limbs with what is in them of wonders and signs after their absence, and enriched him after poverty, and satisfied him after hunger, and clothed him after nakedness, and guided him after misguidance. So look how He managed him and formed him, and to the way [sabil] how He made it easy, and to the transgression of man [insan] how ungrateful he is, and to the ignorance of man [insan] how He made it manifest? So He said: "Does man [insan] not consider that We created him from a sperm-drop [nutfa], and at once he is a clear adversary? And of His signs is that He created you from dust [turab], then, at once, you are human beings dispersing." So look.

a.g: Then He causes his death and provides a grave for him.

Know that arrogance [kibr] is among the destructive traits, and no one among creation is free from some measure of it. Its removal is an individual obligation [fard 'ayn], and it is not removed by mere wishing, but rather by treatment and employing the remedies that suppress it. In its treatment are two stations: the first is the eradication of its root from its origin and the uprooting of its tree from its planting place in the heart [qalb]. The second is repelling its incidental manifestations through the causes by which a person becomes arrogant over others. The first station is in eradicating its root, and its treatment is both intellectual ['ilmi] and practical ['amali], and the cure is not complete except by their combination. As for the intellectual: it is that he knows his own soul [nafs] and knows his Lord, the Exalted, and that suffices him in removing arrogance [kibr]. For whenever he knows his own soul [nafs] with true knowledge [ma'rifa], he knows that he is more abased than every abased one and less than every insignificant one, and that nothing befits him except humility [tawadu'] and abasement and lowliness. And when he knows his Lord, he knows that grandeur ['azama] and majesty [kibriya'] are not fitting except for Allah. As for his knowledge [ma'rifa] of his Lord and His grandeur and His glory, speech on that is lengthy, and it is the ultimate knowledge [ma'rifa] of unveiling [mukashafa]. As for his knowledge [ma'rifa] of his own soul [nafs], it is also lengthy, but we mention from it what is beneficial in arousing humility [tawadu'] and abasement. It suffices him to know the meaning of a single verse in the Book of Allah, for the Qur'an is the knowledge ['ilm] of the former and the later peoples for whom his insight [basira] has been opened. And He, the Exalted, has said: "Cursed is man; how disbelieving he is! From what thing did He create him? From a sperm-drop [nutfa] He created him and proportioned him. Then He made the way easy for him. Then He causes him to die and puts him in a grave. Then when He wills, He will resurrect him." (80:17-22) Indeed, the verse has pointed to the first creation of man: he was not a thing mentioned, and he was in the realm of non-existence for ages—indeed, his non-existence had no beginning. And what thing is more vile and less than obliteration and non-existence? He was like that in pre-eternity. Then Allah created him from the vilest of things, then from the filthiest of them, for He created him from dust, then from a sperm-drop [nutfa], then from a clinging clot ['alaqa], then from a lump of flesh [mudgha], then He made him bones, then He clothed the bones with flesh. This was the beginning of his existence, when he became a thing mentioned. He did not become a thing mentioned except while being upon the vilest of descriptions and attributes! For he was not created in his beginning complete; rather, He created him as a lifeless, inanimate object [jamad]—he did not hear, nor see, nor feel, nor move, nor speak, nor grasp, nor perceive, nor know. He began with his death before his life, and with his weakness before his strength, and with his ignorance before his knowledge ['ilm], and with his blindness before his sight, and with his deafness before his hearing, and with his muteness before his speech, and with his misguidance before his guidance, and with his poverty before his wealth, and with his incapacity before his power. This is the meaning of His saying: "From what thing did He create him? From a sperm-drop [nutfa] mixed?" (80:18-19) and the meaning of His saying: "Has there come upon man a period of time when he was not a thing mentioned? Indeed, We created man from a sperm-drop [nutfa] mixed that We may try him." (76:1-2) Likewise, He created him first, then bestowed favor upon him, saying: "Then He made the way easy for him." (80:20) And this is a reference to what was made easy for him during the period of his life until death. And likewise He said: "From a sperm-drop [nutfa] mixed, We try him, so We made him hearing and seeing. Indeed, We guided him to the way, be he grateful or be he ungrateful." (76:2-3) And its meaning is that He gave him life after he was a lifeless, inanimate object [jamad], dead, dust first and a sperm-drop [nutfa] second. And He gave him hearing after he was deaf, and gave him sight after he was lacking vision, and strengthened him after weakness, and gave him knowledge ['ilm] after ignorance, and created for him the limbs with their wonders and signs after their absence, and enriched him after poverty, and satiated him after hunger, and clothed him after nakedness, and guided him after misguidance. So look how He managed him and formed him, and to the way how He made it easy for him, and to the transgression of man, how disbelieving he is, and to the ignorance of man, how He has made it manifest? So He said: "Does man not consider that We created him from a sperm-drop [nutfa] and at once he is a clear adversary? And of His signs is that He created you from dust; then, at once, you are human beings dispersing." (36:77, 20) So look...

a.g: Then when He wills, He will resurrect him.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
أفتكذبينه في قوله ثم إذا شاء أنشرك فإن لم تكونى مكذبة فما لك لا تأخذين حذرك ولو أن يهوديا أخبرك في ألذ أطعمتك بأنه يضرك في مرضك لصبرت عنه وتركته وجاهدت نفسك فيه أفكان قول الأنبياء المؤيدين بالمعجزات وقول الله تعالى في كتبه المنزلة أقل عندك تأثيرا من قول يهودى يخبرك عن حدس وتخمين وظن مع نقصان عقل وقصور علم والعجب أنه لو أخبرك طفل بأن في ثوبك عقربا لرميت ثوبك في الحال من غير مطالبة له بدليل وبرهان أفكان قول الأنبياء والعلماء والحكماء وكافة الأولياء أقل عندك من قول صبى من جملة الأغبياء أم صار حر جهنم وأغلالها وأنكالها وزقومها ومقامعها وصديدها وسمومها وأفاعيها وعقاربها أحقر عندك من عقرب لا تحسين بألمها إلا يوما أو أقل منه ما هذه أفعال العقلاء بل لو انكشف للبهائم حالك لضحكوا منك وسخروا من عقلك فإن كنت يا نفس قد عرفت جميع ذلك وآمنت به فما لك تسوفين العمل والموت لك بالمرصاد ولعله يختطفك من غير مهلة فبماذا أمنت استعجال الأجل وهبك أنك وعدت بالإمهال مائة سنة أفتظنين أن من يطعم الدابة في حضيض العقبة يفلح ويقدر على قطع العقبة بها إن ظننت ذلك فما أعظم جهلك أرأيت لو سافر رجل ليتفقه في الغربة فأقام فيها سنين متعطلا بطالا يعد نفسه بالتفقه فى السنة الأخيرة عند رجوعه إلى وطنه هل كنت تضحكين من عقله وظنه أن تفقيه النفس مما يطمع فيه بمدة قريبة أو حسبانه أن مناصب الفقهاء تنال من غير تفقه اعتمادا على كرم الله سبحانه وتعالى ثم هبى أن الجهد في آخر العمر نافع وأنه موصل إلى الدرجات العلا فلعل اليوم آخر عمرك فلم تشتغلين فيه بذلك فإن أوحى إليك بالإمهال فما المانع من المبادرة وما الباعث لك على التسويف هل له سبب إلا عجزك عن مخالفة شهواتك لما فيها من التعب والمشقة أفتنتظرين يوما يأتيك لا تعسر فيه مخالفة الشهوات هذا يوم لم يخلقه الله قط ولا يخلقه فلا تكون الجنة قط إلا محفوفة بالمكاره ولا تكون
Indeed, do you then disbelieve in His saying, "Then when He wills, He will resurrect you [ansharakum]"? If you are not a disbeliever, then why do you not take your precaution? If a Jew were to inform you, concerning the most delicious of your foods, that it would harm you in your illness, you would abstain from it and leave it, and you would struggle against your soul [nafs] concerning it. Was the saying of the Prophets, supported by miracles, and the saying of God Almighty in His revealed Books, of less impact upon you than the saying of a Jew who informs you based on conjecture [hads] and guesswork and assumption [zann], with deficient intellect and limited knowledge? And the wonder is that if a child were to inform you that there is a scorpion in your garment, you would cast your garment away immediately without demanding from him proof and evidence. Was the saying of the Prophets and the scholars and the wise and all the saints [awliya'] less to you than the saying of a child from among the foolish? Or has the fire of Hell [jahannam] and its shackles and its chains and its Zaqqum and its maces and its pus and its poisonous winds and its serpents and its scorpions become more contemptible to you than a scorpion whose pain you would not feel except for a day or less? What are these actions of the rational? Nay, if your state were unveiled to the beasts, they would laugh at you and mock your intellect. If you, O soul [nafs], have come to know all of that and have believed in it, then why do you procrastinate in work, while death lies in wait for you, and perhaps it will snatch you without respite? With what have you felt secure from the hastening of the appointed term [ajal]? Suppose you were promised a respite of a hundred years—do you think that one who feeds his mount in the pit of the steep pass will succeed and be able to cross the pass with it? If you think that, then how great is your ignorance! Consider, if a man traveled to seek knowledge [tafaqquh] in a foreign land and remained there for years, idle and inactive, promising himself to seek knowledge in the final year upon his return to his homeland—would you not laugh at his intellect and his assumption that instructing the soul [tafqih al-nafs] is something one can aspire to in a short period? Or his reckoning that the stations of the learned are attained without seeking knowledge, relying on the generosity of God, Glorified and Exalted is He? Then suppose that striving at the end of one's life is beneficial and that it leads to the highest degrees [darajat]—perhaps today is the last of your life, so why are you not occupied with that? If it is whispered to you of respite, what prevents you from hastening, and what incites you to procrastination? Does it have any cause except your inability to oppose your appetites [shahawat] due to the toil and hardship in it? Do you await a day that will come to you in which opposing appetites is not difficult? This is a day God has never created, nor will He create it. For Paradise [al-jannah] will never be except surrounded by hardships, nor will the Fire...

a.g: No! Man has not yet accomplished what He commanded him.
Then let mankind look at his food -
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
ثم النبات إذا ارتفع عن الأرض كان في الفواكه انعقاد وصلابة فتفتقر إلى رطوبة تنضجها فانظر كيف خلق القمر وجعل من خاصيته الترطيب كما جعل من خاصية الشمس التسخين فهو ينضج الفواكه ويصبغها بتقدير الفاطر الحكيم ولذلك لو كانت الأشجار في ظل يمنع شروق الشمس والقمر وسائر الكواكب عليها لكانت فاسدة ناقصة حتى إن الشجرة الصغيرة تفسد إذا ظللتها شجرة كبيرة وتعرف... فنقول: كما أن الخشب والتراب لا يغذيك بل تحتاج إلى طعام مخصوص فكذلك الحبة لا تغتذى بكل شىء بل تحتاج إلى شىء مخصوص بدليل أنك لو تركتها في البيت لم تزد لأنه ليس يحيط بها إلا هواء ومجرد الهواء لا يصلح لغذائها ولو تركنها في الماء لم تزد ولو تركنها في أرض لا ماء فيها لم تزد بل لا بد من أرض فيها ماء يمتزج ماؤها بالأرض فيصير طينا وإليه الإشارة بقوله تعالى: ﴿ فلينظر الإنسان إلى طعامه أنا صببنا الماء صبا ثم شققنا الأرض شقا فأنبتنا فيها حبا وعنبا وقضبا وزيتونا ونخلا ﴾ {} الآية ثم لا يكفى الماء والتراب إذ لو تركت في أرض ندية صلبة متراكمة لم تنبت لفقد الهواء فيحتاج إلى تركها في أرض رجوة متخلخلة يتغلغل الهواء إليها ثم الهواء لا يتحرك إليها بنفسه فيحتاج إلى ريح تحرك الهواء وتضربه بقهر وعنف على الأرض حتى ينفذ فيها وإليه الإشارة بقولة تعالى: ﴿ وأرسلنا الرياح لواقح ﴾ {} وإنما إلقاحها في إيقاع الازدواج بين الهواء والماء والأرض ثم كل ذلك لا يغنيك لو كان في برد مفرط وشتاء شات فتحتاج إلى حرارة الربيع والصيف فقد بان احتياج غذائه إلى هذه الأربعة فانظر إلى ماذا يحتاج كل واحد إذ يحتاج الماء لينساق إلى أرض الزراعة من البحار والعيون والأنهار والسواقى فانظر كيف خلق الله البحار وفجر العيون وأجرى منها الأنهار ثم الأرض ربما تكون مرتفعة والمياه لا ترتفع إليها فانظر كيف خلق الله تعالى الغيوم وكيف سلط الرياح عليها لتسوقها بإذنه إلى أقطار الأرض وهى سحب ثقال حوامل بالماء ثم انظر كيف يرسله مدرارا على الأراضى في وقت الربيع والخريف على حسب الحاجة وانظر كيف خلق الجبال حافظة للمياه تتفجر منها العيون تدريجا فلو خرجت دفعة لغرقت البلاد وهلك الزرع والمواشى ونعم الله في الجبال والسحاب والبحار والأمطار لا يمكن إحصاؤها وأما الحرارة فإنها لا تحصل بين الماء والأرض وكلاهما باردان فانظر كيف سخر الشمس وكيف خلقها مع بعدها عن الأرض مسخنة للأرض في وقت دون وقت ليحصل البرد عند الحاجة إلى البرد والحر عند الحاجة إلى الحر فهذه إحدى حكم الشمس والحكم فيها أكثر من أن تحصى
Indeed, let the human [insan] reflect upon his food [ta'am]. We poured down water [ma'] in abundance, then We split the earth [ard] open, splitting, and caused to grow within it grain [habb], and vines [‘inab], and fresh herbage [qadb], and olive trees [zaytun], and date-palms [nakhil]. Then the plant, when it rises from the earth, finds in the fruits a hardening and firmness, so it needs a moisture to ripen them. So look how He created the moon [qamar] and made from its specific property moistening, just as He made from the specific property of the sun [shams] heating. So it ripens the fruits and colors them by the decree of the Creator, the Wise [al-Fatir al-Hakim]. And for that reason, if the trees were in a shade preventing the rising of the sun and the moon and the rest of the stars upon them, they would be corrupt and deficient—to the point that a small tree is corrupted if a large tree shades it, and it is known... So We say: Just as wood and soil do not nourish you, but rather you need a specific food, likewise the seed does not nourish itself with everything, but rather it needs a specific thing. The proof is that if you left it in a house, it would not increase because nothing surrounds it except air [hawa'], and mere air is not suitable for its nourishment. And if you left it in water, it would not increase. And if you left it in an earth containing no water, it would not increase. Rather, it must be in an earth containing water, so that its water mixes with the earth and becomes mud. And to this is the allusion in His saying, the Exalted: "Let the human reflect upon his food. We poured down water in abundance, then We split the earth open, splitting, and caused to grow within it grain, and vines, and fresh herbage, and olive trees, and date-palms" — the verse. Then water and soil are not sufficient, for if you left it in a moist, solid, compacted earth, it would not sprout due to the absence of air. So it needs to be left in a loose, porous earth into which the air penetrates. Then the air does not move to it by itself, so it needs a wind [rih] that moves the air and strikes it with compulsion and violence upon the earth until it penetrates into it. And to this is the allusion in His saying, the Exalted: "And We sent the winds as pollinators" [15:22]. And their pollination is only in effecting the coupling [izdiwaj] between the air and the water and the earth. Then all of that is of no avail to you if it is in extreme cold and harsh winter, so you need the heat of spring and summer. Thus, the need of its nourishment for these four has become clear. So look at what each one needs. For the water needs to flow to the land of cultivation from the seas, springs, rivers, and streams. So look how Allah created the seas and made the springs gush forth and caused rivers to flow from them. Then the earth may be elevated, and the waters do not rise to it. So look how Allah, the Exalted, created the clouds and how He subjected the winds to them to drive them by His permission to the regions of the earth—and they are heavy clouds, carriers of water. Then look how He sends it down pouring upon the lands in the time of spring and autumn according to the need. And look how He created the mountains as preservers of the waters, from which the springs gush forth gradually. If they came out all at once, the lands would be flooded and the crops and livestock would perish. And the blessings of Allah in the mountains, the clouds, the seas, and the rains cannot be enumerated. As for the heat, it is not obtained between the water and the earth, for both of them are cold. So look how He subjugated the sun and how He created it, despite its distance from the earth, to heat the earth at one time and not another, so that cold occurs when there is need for cold, and heat when there is need for heat. This is one of the wisdoms of the sun, and the wisdoms in it are more than can be enumerated.

a.g: How We poured down water in torrents,
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
وقال تعالى: " أفرأيتم ما تحرثون " أضاف إلينا ثم قال تعالى: " أنا صببنا ثم شققنا الأرض شقاً فأنبتنا فيها حباً وعنباً "
Indeed, have you considered what you sow [tahroothoon]? He attributed it to you. Then He, the Exalted, said: Indeed, We pour down [sababna] the water, then We cleave the earth [al-ard] with cleaving, and We cause to grow therein grain [habban] and grapes.

a.g: Then We broke open the earth, splitting [it with sprouts],
And caused to grow within it grain
And grapes and herbage
And olive and palm trees
And gardens of dense shrubbery
And fruit and grass -
[As] enjoyment for you and your grazing livestock.
But when there comes the Deafening Blast
On the Day a man will flee from his brother
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
وعند الله جزاء التقوى "يوم يفر المرء من أخيه وأمه وأبيه" إلا على سبيل الشفاعة لمن لم يشتد غضب الله عليه فيأذن في الشفاعة له - كما سبق في كتاب الكبر والعجب. ومن ظن أنه ينجو بتقوى أبيه كمن ظن أنه يشبع بأكل أبيه ويروى بشرب أبيه، ويصير عالماً بتعلم أبيه ويصل إلى الكعبة ويراها بمشي أبيه. فالتقوى فرض عين فلا يجزه فيه والد عن ولده شيئاً وكذا العكس.
Indeed, with Allah is the reward of God-consciousness [taqwa]. "On the Day a man will flee from his brother, and his mother and his father" — except by way of intercession [shafa'a] for one upon whom the wrath of Allah has not intensified, so He permits intercession for him — as has preceded in the Book of Arrogance and Vanity. And whoever thinks he will be saved by the God-consciousness [taqwa] of his father is like one who thinks he will be satiated by the eating of his father, quenched by the drinking of his father, becomes a knower [alim] by the learning of his father, and reaches the Ka'bah and sees it by the walking of his father. So God-consciousness [taqwa] is an individual obligation [fard 'ayn]; nothing of it from a parent suffices for his child, and likewise the opposite.

a.g: And his mother and his father
And his wife and his children,
For every man, that Day, will be a matter adequate for him.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
قالت سودة زوج النبي ﷺ راوية الحديث قلت يا رسول الله واسوأتاه ينظر بعضنا إلى بعض فقال شغل الناس عن ذلك بهم: ﴿ لكل امرىء يومئذ شأن يغنيه ﴾ {}[147] فأعظم بيوم تنكشف فيه العورات ويؤمن فيه مع ذلك النظر والالتفات كيف وبعضهم يمشون على بطونهم ووجوههم فلا قدرة لهم على الالتفات إلى غيرهم.
Indeed, for every man [kullu imri'in] on that Day [yawma'idhin] will be an affair [sha'nun] that will occupy him [yughnihi]. [80:37] Sawdah, the wife of the Prophet ﷺ and the narrator of the hadith, said: I said, "O Messenger of Allah, how terrible! Will we look at one another?" He said, "The people will be preoccupied from that by their own affair: 'For every man on that Day will be an affair that will occupy him.'" So, contemplate the immensity of a Day [yawm] in which the private parts are exposed, and yet, despite that, looking and turning away is safe. How could it be otherwise, when some of them are walking on their bellies and their faces, having no power to turn towards anyone else?

a.g: [Some] faces, that Day, will be bright -
Laughing, rejoicing at good news.
And [other] faces, that Day, will have upon them dust.
Blackness will cover them.
Those are the disbelievers, the wicked ones.
